entries.title: The giant snail race is one of the carnival's most popular attractions.

entries.name: Snail Racing Rules
entries: Every snail needs a jockey, and any saddles not filled by characters are filled by other attendees (use the {@creature commoner} stat block to represent these NPCs). All the snails and their riders begin at the start line; fireworks signal the start of the race, after which the riders race their snails to the finish line.

On a whiteboard or notepad, jot down the giant snails, their numbers, and their riders. Next to the names, keep a running total of how far each snail travels in feet during the race. The course is 480 feet long.

entries.name: Racing Rules
entries: The race is divided into 6-second rounds. Once the race begins, the snails move along the track at remarkable speed, each one covering 80 feet per round by itself. Without riders, the snails are an even match, but a jockey can try to improve a snail's performance by patting its shell or speaking words of encouragement at it.

Initiative rolls are unnecessary. Once per round, each jockey can make a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a successful check, the jockey's snail moves an extra 10 feet that round, or 20 feet if the check succeeds by 5 or more. On a failed check, the jockey's snail moves 10 feet slower that round, or 20 feet slower if the check fails by 5 or more. The race ends when one or more snails travel the 480 feet needed to cross the finish line.

If two or more snails cross the finish line in the same round, determine the winner of the race by having those snails' jockeys each roll a {@dice d20}. The highest roll determines the winner, with one snail narrowly claiming victory. If the roll for first place is tied, the race ends in a tie, and each winning jockey receives the first-place prize (see "Prizes" below).

Signs posted in the stands and along the racetrack warn that neither jockeys nor spectators may influence the outcome of a race by using magic or by harming other jockeys or snails. Any jockey who openly does so is disqualified, as is the jockey's snail. A spectator caught doing so is escorted from the carnival by {@dice 1d4} {@creature Goblin||goblins} (lawful good) who are watching the crowd closely for troublemakers.

entries.name: Surprises
entries: At the start of each round after the first, roll a {@dice d8} and consult the Snail Race Surprises table to determine if something unexpected happens that round. When a surprise occurs, determine which snail is affected by rolling a {@dice d8}.

entries.caption: Snail Race Surprises
rows: No surprise.
One random snail gets a stitch, reducing its speed by 40 feet this round.
A spectator throws a head of lettuce at one random snail. The snail stops to eat the lettuce and doesn't move at all this round.
One random snail is bolstered by the cheering crowd and moves an extra 20 feet this round.

The saddle on one random snail comes loose and falls off. The snail's jockey must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw to remain atop the snail. On a failed save, the jockey falls off, and the snail continues the race on its own.

entries.name: Prizes
entries: The jockey whose snail wins the race receives a {@item potion of advantage|orcnogTWC}. The jockey whose snail comes in last receives a consolation prize, provided they weren't disqualified. The consolation prize is a magic wand that allows its holder to cast the {@spell dancing lights} cantrip once. Once used to cast this spell, the wand turns into a tulip.

entries.name: Staff Area

entries: A tangled wall of thorns surrounds a cluster of wagons lit by lanterns. This caravan is barely visible through the thicket.

The carnival's wagons are located behind the Big Top, protected by a 20-foot-high, 5-foot-thick wall of thorns. When a member of the carnival staff stands within 1 foot of the wall, the thorns part to form an 8-foot-high, 4-foot-wide doorway in front of the staff member. This door remains open for 10 seconds, then disappears as thorny vines fill the opening once more. The wall is magical and also impervious to damage. The wall grants {@book three-quarters cover|PHB|9|Cover} to creatures behind it.

A creature can move through the wall of thorns, albeit slowly and painfully. It costs 8 feet of movement to move through 1 foot of the wall. The first time a creature enters the wall on a turn or ends its turn there, it must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@dice 1d8}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Whenever a creature ends its turn in the wall, trumpet-shaped flowers burst from the brambles nearby and honk an alarm that is audible up to 50 feet away.

entries.name: Circle of Wagons
entries: Enclosed by the wall of thorns is a circle of eight brightly painted wagons, one of which is a glass-enclosed water tank for Palasha the mermaid. The fanciest of the remaining seven wagons belongs to {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC}.

The perimeter inside the wall of thorns and outside the circle of wagons is patrolled by a {@creature bugbear} named Burly (neutral good), who leaves his post once during the evening to participate in the {@area Big Top Extravaganza|0f0}.  While on patrol, Burly wears a large jack-o'-lantern on his head, as one would wear a helmet, in addition to his dungarees and fake fairy wings.

The central area enclosed by the wagons is guarded by Thaco the clown, a human {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|orcnogTWC|Witchlight hand} (chaotic neutral; see the stat block earlier in the chapter) who is loyal only to {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC}. He usually sits right outside the door to Witch and Light's wagon, blowing bubbles with his bubble pipe.
Burly and Thaco dislike each other, so they don't fraternize while on guard duty.
Characters caught snooping around the wagons without an escort are evicted from the carnival and must find a way to sneak or barter their way back in.

entries.name: Witch and Light's Wagon
entries: {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} (see their stat blocks earlier in the chapter) are in their wagon throughout the evening, except during the Big Top Extravaganza (which Light attends and Witch does not) and the crowning of the Witchlight Monarch (which they both attend). See {@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x} later in the chapter for more information.
Refer to the "Carnival Owners" section for more information about Witch and Light.
Characters who sneak up to the wagon while it's occupied can overhear Witch and Light talking:
Two contrasting voices emanate from the wagon.
{@i Mister Witch, in a low and gravelly voice:} "You need to find a way to calm down."
{@i Mister Light, in a high-pitched, shrill voice:} "I'll calm down when that kenku pest is gone."
{@i Witch}: "He'll tire out soon enough and be on his way."
{@i Light}: "I hope you're right."

From there, the conversation shifts to the current mood of the carnival and ideas for new carnival acts or attractions ("The catoblepas didn't work out, but maybe we can buy a giraffe and paint it blue. Or we could teach Northwind how to play the fiddle.")

If the characters disturb Witch and Light in their wagon without being invited, jump ahead to the "{@area Inside the Wagon|0e0|x}" encounter described later in the chapter, skipping over the lead-in with Burly and Thaco.

entries.name: Searching the Wagon
entries: {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC}'s bunk is neat and unadorned. {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC}'s bunk is gaudy and messy, with costumes strewn everywhere. Characters who search through the gear find a hatbox containing the crown of the Witchlight Monarch; this splendid crown of gold butterflies teleports back to its hatbox at the end of each evening and is ceremoniously produced from its box during the monarch's coronation (see "{@area Crowning the Witchlight Monarch|0f2|x}" later in the chapter).

Any character who searches the wagon for secret compartments finds one with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check. The compartment is located in a bench and contains a tiny, bejeweled chest worth 50 gp. This chest is a replica of a much larger chest hidden on the Ethereal Plane (with the help of a {@spell Leomund's secret chest} spell). While holding the replica chest, {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} can use an action to summon the larger chest. He can send the larger chest back to the Ethereal Plane by using an action and touching both the chest and the replica.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest hidden on the Ethereal Plane (which is worth 5,000 gp) contains recent earnings (210 sp and 70 gp), a {@item potion of diminution}, a {@item potion of growth}, and a {@item potion of advantage|orcnogTWC}. The potions are not labeled, but {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} knows which is which.

entries.name: Carnival Events
entries: This section describes special events that occur during the characters' visit to the carnival.

entries.name: Catching Kester
entries: {@creature Kester the Kenku|orcnogTWC|Kester} (see the accompanying stat block) snoops around the carnival under the cover of a {@spell disguise self} spell, looking to cause trouble. The kenku has stolen the voice of a human mime named Candlefoot (see "{@area Hall of Illusions|0a6|x}" earlier in the chapter). While this prize remains in his possession, Kester can speak clearly in Candlefoot's soft, silky voice.

If Kester has not already been caught, a character who spends 1 hour searching for the disguised kenku can, with a successful DC 13 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check, see through his disguise while moving through crowds and paying close attention to suspicious-looking folks. If discovered, Kester tries to flee from the main thoroughfare, using tents and other carnival features to break line of sight to her. He's willing to cautiously parley with characters who claim they are investigating the carnival for their own reasons.

entries.name: Talking with Kester
entries: If the characters corner him, Kester tells his story in the voice he stole from Candlefoot:

items: Kester was hired by a rival carnival, The Harlem and Haley Brother's Circus. The circus usually does decent business, but every 8 years when the Witchlight Carnival comes to the Material Plane, they nearly go bankrupt.
He was hired with the objective of stirring up trouble, lowering the mood of the carnival, and generally hurting business. Their loss is Harlem and Haley's gain.

He's being paid handsomely to wreak havoc. A DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check can convince Kester to tell them his price: 500 gp. With a roll of 20 or higher, Kester will consider an offer to outbid his employers (double or more) in order to buy him out.
A DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check can convince Kester to leave the carnival and never return.

entries: If questioned about the theft of Candlefoot's voice, Kester produces a corn husk doll with a thorny stem tied around its neck. The doll represents Candlefoot, and untying the stem restores the mime's lost voice. Any character who succeeds on a DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Persuasion}) check can convince Kester to part with the doll.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the characters reunite Candlefoot with his voice, Candlefoot seeks out Palasha and proposes marriage to her. Reuniting the couple causes the carnival's mood to rise by 2 steps (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}" earlier in the chapter, and roll on the {@item Mood Rises|orcnogTWC|Mood Rises} table). From that point on, Palasha and Candlefoot treat the characters as trusted allies, which could prove useful during the crowning of the Witchlight Monarch, as they both have roles to play in the coronation.
{@note The following events occur at specific times throughout the evening.}

entries.name: Hour 1: Welcome Gifts
entries: Shortly after the carnival opens for business, read:

A twelve-foot-tall walking tree garlanded in golden ribbons marches down the thoroughfare. Emerald clouds swirl above the tree and rain down golden, spinning sycamore seeds. Fairgoers try to catch the seeds before they hit the ground. As the seeds gently fall, a chatty squirrel scampers along the boughs of the tree, handing dandelions to select passersby.

The tree is Northwind, a {@creature treant sapling|WBtW} (see its stat block earlier in the chapter), and the squirrel is its trusty companion, Red (see "{@area Dragonfly Rides|09a|x}" earlier in the chapter). As Northwind encourages onlookers to catch the falling seeds before they touch the ground, Red hands the characters one dandelion apiece and encourages each of them to make a wish and then blow the dandelion's seeds into the air.

entries.name: Sycamore Seeds
entries: A creature can attempt to catch a falling sycamore seed before it touches the ground, doing so with a successful DC 10 Dexterity check. Any creature that catches a seed before it touches the ground receives a gift, determined by rolling a {@dice d8} and consulting the Welcome Gifts table. A creature that receives one of these gifts can't gain another one for 24 hours.

entries.name: Dandelion Seeds
entries: A character can make a wish while blowing their dandelion's seeds into the air. The player should secretly write down their character's wish on a piece of paper; collect these notes and keep them somewhere safe.

entries.caption: Welcome Gifts
rows: The creature gains the following personality trait until dawn: "I am easily amused." Any conflicting character trait is suppressed in the meantime.
The creature gains a die, a {@dice d4}, which it can add to one ability check it makes before the next dawn.
The seed turns into a gold piece.
The creature gains a die, a {@dice d8}, which it can add to one ability check it makes before the next dawn.

entries.name: Hour 4: Big Top Extravaganza
entries: Spectators file into the Big Top and fill the rows of seats. If the characters join them, read:

The lights dim and a hush falls over the crowd. A second later, a spotlight illuminates a lithe, elven figure sitting in a silver hoop, suspended above the center ring by silk ropes. The elf wears a dazzling suit of diamond-pane mirrors and a pair of butterfly wings. His scepter is topped with a spinning vane.
"Welcome, one and all, to this evening's extravaganza! I am {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC}. Prepare to be delighted!"

The extravaganza involves several of the carnival's star performers and attractions, with {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} serving as ringmaster. Over the course of an hour, the following events occur:

Burly the bugbear performs feats of strength, Palasha the mermaid serenades the audience from a clamshell bathing pool, Candlefoot the mime plays silent games with audience members, and faerie dragons with bright streamers tied to their tails perform dazzling acts of synchronized flying as a troupe of acrobats, clowns, and fire-breathers parade about. If the characters attempt to disrupt the show, {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} deflects their interruptions with banter and maintains a jovial demeanor. Persistent heckling lowers the carnival's mood by 1 step (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}" earlier in the chapter, and roll on the {@item Mood Lowers|orcnogTWC|Mood Lowers} table).

entries.name: Burly the Bugbear's Feats of Strength

entries: Walking out of a cloud of smoke and light, a massive, hairy Bugbear, wearing dungarees and a pumpkin helmet, steps out onto the stage, flexing his impressive muscles. He carries an enormous metal pole, easily at least twenty feet long, and it glints under the lights.

{@creature bugbear|Burly the Bugbear} will offer for volunteers from the crowd to hang off each end of the pole, and he will lift them: first one on each end, then two, then three, pausing for applause from the audience in between each feat of strength. Burly is capable of lifting 900lbs without needing to do any kind of ability check: the average human weighs approximately 150lbs. If it seems likely that the weight of the volunteers modifier, with the DC being the Con score of the heaviest volunteer on the pole.

After these feats of strength, two {@creature Goblin} stage hands dressed as jesters wheel out a large tub of water and a long rope: Burly will challenge anyone in the audience to a tug of war, and will even welcome two opponents at once!

The tug of war takes the form of a contested {@skill Athetics} check (Burly has a +6 bonus). If two characters are on one end of the rope, one can use the Help action on the other to give them Advantage on the roll. The loser will get pulled into the water with a dramatic splash.

Defeating Burly earns raucous applause from the crowd, as the Bugbear will lift the contestants above his head to celebrate their victory. Even if a character loses, Burly will help them out of the pool and encourage the audience to applaud their effort.

entries.name: Palasha's Serenade

entries: A giant clamshell is wheeled out, and the lights go down. The lid slowly begins to open in complete silence, until an unearthly, beautiful voice begins to undulate from within: suddenly the lights come up and reveal Palasha the Mermaid, who sings in Aquan, a language that sounds like it's being sung underwater even though you're sitting on dry land. Bubbles of water begin to ripple through the air around her, causing the lights of the tent to shimmer and ripple.

As she sings, {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|orcnogTWC|Witchlight hands} move through the audience handing out sea creature kites that seem to swim through the air as you hold their string. They will gesture to the stage and encourage the party to join the crowd of children who are excitedly making an underwater scene with their animated kite puppets.

rows: Kite
Dolphin
Jellyfish
Shark
Stingray
Seahorse
Sea Serpent
Octopus
Mermaid

entries: Have each character make a DC 14 {@skill Performance} check, as they describe how they play with their kite during the song.

After the performance finishes, Palasha will gesture to the puppeteers for their own round of applause. Anyone who passed the Performance check recieves a fish scale with one use of the Shape Water cantrip from a {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|orcnogTWC|Witchlight Hand} as they collect the kites back up.

entries.name: Candlefoot's Games

entries: A pale, lanky mime dressed in black and white moves through the crowd, followed by the sounds of laughter and delight.

Candlefoot the mime will perform tricks of sleight of hand with the audience. His favorite act is to seemingly slide a copper piece into one ear, ask the audience member to tap their head, and then he'll pull the coin out of the other. He will do this with multiple audience members, until he finds a party member.

This time, he puts a copper in, but pulls out a gold. Expressing shock, he polishes it, he bites it, and he looks closely in the character's ear. He tentatively puts another copper in, and lo and behold, another gold comes out. He excitedly pulls out all the copper pieces he has in his pockets and appears to pour them all into the character's head before waiting eagerly at the other side for his payout... which comes as only one single copper piece.
Dejected, he inspects the players ear, taps on their head and listens, then shrugs sadly, turns out his pockets, and sulks sadly away, as the audience sighs "Aaaaaaw".

He'll hold out his hand for donations and cheer up more and more with every gift. Any character who gives Candlefoot a gold piece receives a gift of thanks with a sly wink: a sachet of {@item pixie dust|orcnogTWC}.

entries.name: Open Mic
entries: Near the end of the show, {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} asks if any guests would like to perform their own acts for the crowd. Any character who accepts the offer can woo spectators with a DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check, raising the carnival's mood by 1 step on a success (roll on the {@item Mood Rises|orcnogTWC|Mood Rises} table). If multiple characters choose to perform together, make it a group check instead, but raise the carnival's mood by 2 steps if the group check succeeds (roll once on the {@item Mood Rises|orcnogTWC|Mood Rises} table). A character can improve the carnival's mood only once during this extravaganza.

At the end of the show, Burly invites any characters who took to the stage and impressed the crowd to meet with {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} (see "{@area Meeting Witch and Light|0dd|x}" earlier in the chapter).

entries.name: Extravaganza Finale

entries: As the show comes to close, a dozen Faerie Dragons with bright streamers tied to their tails perform dazzling acts of synchronized flying as a troupe of acrobats, clowns, and firebreathers parade about. The slender, colourful Mr Light brandishes his scepter high above his head and invites anyone from the audience on stage to perform for the crowd. As he does, several giggling children run up immediately and start dancing and falling over.
If {@creature Kester the Kenku|orcnogTWC|Kester} is still at large in the carnival, he can attempt to sabotage the party's performance, which otherwise plays out as written in the adventure:

items: A {@creature Smoke Mephit|MM} that is part of a firebreather's act will begin to cough and sneeze uncontrollably as {@creature Kester the Kenku|orcnogTWC|Kester} uses {@spell Mage Hand} to tickle its nose. All party members on stage will be subject to its Cinder Breath ability, after which it will apologise profusely.
Using {@spell Minor Illusion}, a board reading "BOO" will appear above the party's heads, causing some of the audience to start jeering them.
{@creature Kester the Kenku|orcnogTWC|Kester} sneaks on stage, disguised as a {@creature Commoner}, and uses his Twilight Sleep ability to engulf one character in sleep-inducing gas mid-performance.
Disguised as a Witchlight Hand, Kester will brush by another party member and use {@spell Bestow Curse} to give them disadvantage on all Charisma checks.

entries.name: Hour 8: Crowning the Witchlight Monarch
entries: Most of the carnival's stars have a part to play in the coronation, which celebrates the joyous zeal of a single guest. The event plays out as follows:

items: As spectators take their seats in the Big Top, Dirlagraun the displacer beast escorts {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} from his wagon to the coronation, leaving Thaco the clown behind to guard the Staff Area.

{@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and Dirlagraun stand on the sidelines next to Candlefoot as {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} gives an opening speech and the monarch is selected (see "Selecting a Monarch" below). Candlefoot holds the hatbox containing the monarch's crown.

{@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} removes the crown of golden butterflies from the hatbox and places it on the monarch's head; {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} knights the monarch with the {@item Witchlight vane|orcnogTWC}. Happy clowns shower all three in glitter.
Witch and Light escort the monarch on a circuit of the stage while Palasha the mermaid sings a joyous song and pixies flutter all around her.

When Palasha's song concludes, {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} leads the monarch on a parade through the carnival, with the other guests following as Burly the bugbear sets off fireworks. Meanwhile, Dirlagraun escorts {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} back to his wagon.

entries.name: Selecting a Monarch
entries: {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC}'s {@item Witchlight vane|orcnogTWC} selects the monarch from the carnival's guests, spinning a thread of golden light that winds its way to the chosen reveler. If the mood of the carnival is positive, choose the character who improved the carnival's mood the most, or ask the players to agree on which of their characters should be crowned. If it's not appropriate for any of the characters to be crowned monarch, then a jubilant halfling bedecked in flowers is selected from the crowd. {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} exudes cheerfulness and follows through with the ceremony regardless of who is chosen.

At the end of the celebration, as the carnival begins to wind down, the ceremonial crown teleports back into its hatbox. Candlefoot returns the hatbox to the Staff Area, handing it off to Thaco the clown, who stashes it in the wagon belonging to {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC}.

entries.name: Development
entries: The Witchlight Monarch gains the following charm (see "{@book Supernatural Gifts|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts}" in the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for more information) and instantly becomes aware of its benefits:

entries.name: Charm of the Monarch
entries: You can sprout a pair of beautiful butterfly wings. As long as you have the wings, you gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed, and you gain a +5 bonus on all Charisma-based ability checks. These effects last for 1 hour. After you use this charm three times, it vanishes from you.

entries.name: Through the Looking Glass
entries: The characters receive an invitation to meet privately with {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} when the carnival's mood reaches either end of the track (see "{@area Tracking Mood|065|x}" earlier in the chapter) or if the characters impress {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} during the Big Top Extravaganza (see "{@area Big Top Extravaganza|0f0|x}" later in the chapter).
Witch and Light send Burly the {@creature bugbear} (neutral good) to fetch the characters:
A bugbear wearing dungarees, fairy wings, and a helmet made from a jack-o'-lantern approaches you. "Follow me," he growls. "Management wants to see you."

With a wave of his hand, Burly creates an opening in the wall of thorns that surrounds the staff wagons (see "Staff Area" above) and leads the characters through it. If questioned about the nature of the meeting, Burly insists there's nothing to worry about. If the carnival's mood is good, he adds that his bosses are in high spirits.
If the characters follow Burly, read:

The bugbear leads you to a circle of wagons. Leaning against a particularly ostentatious wagon is an aging clown with a painted grin. He puffs on a bubble pipe and glares at you as the bugbear, ignoring the clown, opens the wagon's door and ushers you inside.
The clown is Thaco, a human {@creature Witchlight Hand (Medium)|orcnogTWC|Witchlight hand} (chaotic neutral; see the stat block earlier in the chapter) and over-the-hill carnival attraction.

entries.title: {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} don't like strangers eavesdropping on their private conversations

entries.name: Inside the Wagon

entries: A flamboyant elf grins from ear to ear as he welcomes you into the wagon with a theatrical bow. "Please come in, it's a delight to meet you all! I am {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC}, and this is my associate, {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC}."
He gestures to a stocky elf lounging on a bunk. {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} nods to you and doffs his top hat.
Stat blocks for {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} appear earlier in the chapter.

{@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} gestures toward his scepter—the {@item Witchlight vane|orcnogTWC}—and explains that it picks up every nuance of emotion in the carnival. If the carnival's mood is good, Light expresses his gratitude for the cheer that the characters have brought to the carnival so far. If the carnival's mood is bad, he expresses his regret that the characters aren't having a delightful time and notes that, in turn, they're spoiling everyone's evening.

Witch and Light are eager to learn the characters' reasons for visiting the carnival. When the characters mention that they are looking for a fabled magic shop, {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC}'s eyes light up and he says "Ooo, more clients! Mr. Garfield will be pleased!".
The carnival owners lead them to the Hall of Illusions and march them inside:

As Witch and Light move through the Hall of Illusions, their reflections in the mirrors show them as gloomy shadar-kai children, with your own youthful reflections following behind. Soon, they call you to a halt. The mirrors now reflect everyone's true age.

{@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} addresses you. "Everything you seek and more lies beyond this mirror. If you mean to step through, then stand in front of the glass and repeat this rhyme: Fantasy Costco, where all your dreams come true. We got a deal for you!"
{@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} adds in a hushed tone, "I must warn you. The deals are out of this world."
Witch and Light will also share the following information if asked:

items: The pocket dimension beyond the mirror is called Fantasy Costco, wherein dwells the store owner, Garfield the Deals Warlock, who loves nothing more than to make a deal.
Time flows differently and unpredictably in Fantasy Costco. When the heros come back to this plane of existence, they may find that several days or only seconds have passed.
When the heros leave Fantasy Costo through the same portal they entered in, they'll no longer be at the carnival; it will deposit them back into their beds at the last location they long rested.

If they are questioned about conversations that were overheard (see "{@area Witch and Light's Wagon|0d8|x}" above and "{@area Catching Kester|0e7|x}" below), Witch and Light admit they're not the carnival's original owners and took over management through an honest pact with the owner of another carnival.
If asked about Kester, Witch and Light say he's "a troublemaker from a competing carnival who just wants to stir up chaos and ruin everyone's fun.

entries.name: Stepping Through
entries: When a character recites Witch's rhyme while standing in front of their present-day reflection in the Hall of Illusions, read:
Mist swirls in the mirror, blotting out your reflection.

Any creature that touches the surface of the misty mirror is pulled through it and deposited in Fantasy Costco. If a character tries to take either the {@item Witchlight watch|orcnogTWC} or the {@item Witchlight vane|orcnogTWC} through the mirror, the item drops to the floor as the character crosses the threshold. Neither item can be taken into the pocket dimension.
If {@creature Mister Witch|orcnogTWC} and {@creature Mister Light|orcnogTWC} are both present, they wait until only one character remains and then impart the following information to that character:
Give your player some prophetic guidance in their larger campaign quest here. Such as "when the time is right, follow the white rabbit".
Proceed with {@adventure chapter 2|WBtW|2} once the characters pass through the magic mirror.
